Well, that was The Apopalyptics with their anti-tax-avoidance rap Money on an Island. The group made that to try and lobby European governments to clamp down on tax avoidance while multinationals use loopholes to avoid paying up. But now the spotlight is switching to Africa. At United Nations conference in Addis Ababa today rich and poor countries around the world agreed to improve tax collection and clamp down on tax evasion. But there were some controversies. Some poorer nations expressed their reservations about the initiative being led by the OECD, a group often described as the rich club of nations. Ed Butler has been following the story. He told me more about the deal. So a lot of the efforts around this conference have been on the issue of tax. I mean development aid of course is about all kinds of things but tax is the one that's very much galvanised people. You all remember that recent scandals in the UK and the US over tax avoidance by Internet firms like Apple, Google and Amazon. That was the allegation. Everybody wants to plug that. Alvin Musioma, he's head of the Tax Justice Network for Africa and he says that African countries specifically are suffering up to $100 billion of losses every year as a result of this kind of fraud.
